<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LABOR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Buffalo-Starbucks-workers-union-vote?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
That's a Venti Union Election for...Strabusk?
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Buffalo-Starbucks-workers-union-vote?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="A Starbucks cup is stuffed full of union voting ballots." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2dbe5227f2f6c88ceb3124ef51caa6ecb87c7bc6-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-07/starbucks-bid-to-halt-union-vote-count-rejected-by-labor-board?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rejected Starbucks’s bid</a> on Tuesday to delay a union election at three Buffalo-area locations. On the bright side for the company, the NLRB spelled their name correctly.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With the last-ditch effort to pause the election unsuccessful, Starbucks will now await the results of Thursday’s union vote count. Ballots are due today for all three locations—each store will have its own election.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Those separate “store-by-store” elections were the subject of Starbucks’s request to delay. The company argued that a union vote should be regional and involve all 20 chain locations in the area—a move that would favor Starbucks, as union organizers would have to secure a much larger number of votes.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">All eyes on blustery Buffalo</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Although the organizing campaign concerns just three stores (with about 100 employees total), it’s become the focus of national attention. High profile supporters including Sen. Bernie Sanders on labor’s side and dozens of Starbucks corporate executives on management’s side have waded into the union drive. If any of the three elections are successful, the location would be the first corporate-run Starbucks store in the US to unionize. (Name idea: Steamsters. Just throwing it out there.)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For a chain with 9,000 US corporate-owned locations, Starbucks has poured a trenta amount of energy on stopping the union drive.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>President of Starbucks North America, Rossann Williams, visited a Buffalo location in September and </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/SBWorkersUnited/status/1438508591132987395?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">began sweeping floors</a></span><span> there.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Former CEO Howard Schultz gave a </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/noamscheiber/status/1457911697654652930?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">strange talk</a></span><span> to Buffalo-area employees four days before ballots were mailed out.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Starbucks transferred several voting-eligible employees to two of the Buffalo locations. One store, which in August had about 20 eligible employees unanimously in support of unionizing, now has 46 eligible employees, according to Starbucks.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Just 10.8% of the US workforce belonged to a union in 2020, and corporations would prefer it that way (or less). Kellogg’s, one of several US companies to face a strike from unionized employees in recent months, said on Tuesday that it would permanently replace its striking workers.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Biden-Putin-talk-tension-Ukraine-Russia?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Biden and Putin Play 'Risk' IRL
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-warns-putin-strong-response-if-russia-invades-ukraine-n1285523?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">chatted</a> for more than two hours yesterday in a high-stakes meeting over the future of Ukraine.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Russia, you see, has <a href="https://www.gzeromedia.com/is-putin-going-to-invade-ukraine?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">amassed ~100,000 troops</a> at the Ukraine border, and Western countries are worried Putin is planning to invade his neighbor to the west in early 2022. It’s not entirely clear what Russia’s ultimate goal is, but the show of force is concerning to Western governments that want to maintain stability in Europe.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Russia and Ukraine have a history. Ukraine was a Soviet republic until it gained independence in 1991, and in 2014 Russia annexed the country’s Crimean Peninsula.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>More than 14,000 people have died in the conflict since.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How will the West punch back? </strong>In the event of an invasion, it will do to Russia’s economy what Michigan did to Ohio State. Punishments could include putting sanctions on Russia’s banks, making it harder for Russia to convert roubles to dollars, and pressuring Germany to block a pipeline that would allow Russia to sell more gas to Europe.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Stress levels are high along the Eastern front. Don’t believe us? Here’s what Ukraine’s official Twitter account posted yesterday.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/19252186c319df7efa3d7a58a23f8f5006b12a76-514x583.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format" alt="Tweet from Ukraine's Twitter account showing stress levels residing next to Russia" style="display:block;width:100% !important">
</div>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Instagram-New-Safety-Features-Teens?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Instagram to Teens: Let’s Take a Break
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Instagram-New-Safety-Features-Teens?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Lady Bird Teen Phone" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=335 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-26/image-8fb6925f9399a5ac88b34c03ac4389a88358e5bf-480x240-gif/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Lady Bird Teen Phone" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-26/image-8fb6925f9399a5ac88b34c03ac4389a88358e5bf-480x240-gif/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Giphy</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But they mean it in a Ross and Rachel kind of way. Yesterday, Instagram <a href="https://about.instagram.com/blog/announcements/raising-the-standard-for-protecting-teens-and-supporting-parents-online?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> new safety features for teens, including a pop-up reminder to “take a break” from the app when they’ve been scrolling too long.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The announcement comes just one day ahead of when CEO Adam Mosseri will testify before Congress on the effects of Instagram on teens’ mental health.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s what else is new:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Users will be restricted from tagging and mentioning teens who don’t follow them.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Teens will be “nudged” when they’ve spent too much time “dwelling” on one topic.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Parents and guardians will be able to view (and limit) how much time their teenage kids spend on Instagram.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of these features are already rolling out, while others are set to hit the app in January.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Teens have ghosted Instagram from the get-go, and we mean that literally because their favorite social media platform is Snapchat, followed by TikTok, per a survey by Piper Sandler. That’s despite Instagram’s <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/16/technology/instagram-teens.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">best efforts</a> to win them over: It copied Stories from Snapchat in 2016, and since 2018 it has reportedly spent nearly its entire marketing budget targeting teens, per the NYT.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>The top 0.01% of individuals <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/pandemic-boosts-super-rich-share-global-wealth-2021-12-07/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">own 11%</a> of global wealth, according to the new World Inequality Report 2022, up from 10% last year. That top 0.01% includes 520,000 adults with household wealth of at least $19 million.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“OH-mee-kraan”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of y’all don’t know how to pronounce certain variants and it shows. The US Captioning Company released its list of the <a href="https://apnews.com/article/2021-most-mispronounced-words-69604f93fb8ed6e61f8b6848704eaaf6?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most mispronounced words</a> for this year, which includes cheugy (CHOO-gee), ethereum (ih-THEE-ree-um) and the Greek tennis player Stefanos Tsitsipas (STEH-fuh-nohs TSEE-tsee-pas).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>I’m the TikTok couch guy. Here’s what it was like being investigated on the internet. </div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/companies-are-increasing-wages?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
We’re All Getting a Raise
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">2022 could be the year you finally buy that Dyson vacuum cleaner, because companies plan to <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-plan-big-raises-for-workers-in-2022-11638889200?mod=hp_lead_pos10" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fatten up</a> paychecks more than they have in over a decade, according to a Conference Board survey previewed by the WSJ yesterday. They’re setting aside an average of 3.9% of next year’s total payroll for wage increases.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s a sign that salaries will continue to rise in 2022, like they have been doing all year:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Private-sector hourly pay rose 4.8% last month compared to Nov. 2020, the fifth straight month wages have risen more than 4%, the Labor Department reported Friday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Compensation including wages and benefits rose faster in the third quarter of this year than at any other point on record.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why now? </strong>Due to the ongoing labor shortage, employers are paying up to attract and retain the best and brightest. Plus, the cost of living is increasing: Almost four-in-ten of the companies surveyed said they factored inflation into their decisions to increase pay.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But beware of the “<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/why-is-inflation-bad?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wage–price spiral</a>.” When companies raise wages to combat inflation, they’re often forced to raise prices on consumers, which leads to even more inflation.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThat's a Venti Union Election for...Strabusk?\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A Starbucks cup is stuffed full of union voting ballots.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2dbe5227f2f6c88ceb3124ef51caa6ecb87c7bc6-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-07/starbucks-bid-to-halt-union-vote-count-rejected-by-labor-board?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erejected Starbucks’s bid\u003c/a\u003e on Tuesday to delay a union election at three Buffalo-area locations. On the bright side for the company, the NLRB spelled their name correctly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith the last-ditch effort to pause the election unsuccessful, Starbucks will now await the results of Thursday’s union vote count. Ballots are due today for all three locations—each store will have its own election.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThose separate “store-by-store” elections were the subject of Starbucks’s request to delay. The company argued that a union vote should be regional and involve all 20 chain locations in the area—a move that would favor Starbucks, as union organizers would have to secure a much larger number of votes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAll eyes on blustery Buffalo\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAlthough the organizing campaign concerns just three stores (with about 100 employees total), it’s become the focus of national attention. High profile supporters including Sen. Bernie Sanders on labor’s side and dozens of Starbucks corporate executives on management’s side have waded into the union drive. If any of the three elections are successful, the location would be the first corporate-run Starbucks store in the US to unionize. (Name idea: Steamsters. Just throwing it out there.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor a chain with 9,000 US corporate-owned locations, Starbucks has poured a trenta amount of energy on stopping the union drive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003ePresident of Starbucks North America, Rossann Williams, visited a Buffalo location in September and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SBWorkersUnited/status/1438508591132987395?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebegan sweeping floors\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e there.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFormer CEO Howard Schultz gave a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/noamscheiber/status/1457911697654652930?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estrange talk\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to Buffalo-area employees four days before ballots were mailed out.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eStarbucks transferred several voting-eligible employees to two of the Buffalo locations. One store, which in August had about 20 eligible employees unanimously in support of unionizing, now has 46 eligible employees, according to Starbucks.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eJust 10.8% of the US workforce belonged to a union in 2020, and corporations would prefer it that way (or less). Kellogg’s, one of several US companies to face a strike from unionized employees in recent months, said on Tuesday that it would permanently replace its striking workers.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" Russian President Vladimir Putin \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-warns-putin-strong-response-if-russia-invades-ukraine-n1285523?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" href=\"https://www.gzeromedia.com/is-putin-going-to-invade-ukraine?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px in early 2022. It’s not entirely clear what Russia’s ultimate goal is, but the show of force is concerning to Western governments that want to maintain stability in Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRussia and Ukraine have a history. Ukraine was a Soviet republic until it gained independence in 1991, and in 2014 Russia annexed the country’s Crimean Peninsula.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMore than 14,000 people have died in the conflict since.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow will the West punch back? \u003c/strong\u003eIn the event of an invasion, it will do to Russia’s economy what Michigan did to Ohio State. Punishments could include putting sanctions on Russia’s banks, making it harder for Russia to convert roubles to dollars, and pressuring Germany to block a pipeline that would allow Russia to sell more gas to Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eStress levels are high along the Eastern front. href=\"https://about.instagram.com/blog/announcements/raising-the-standard-for-protecting-teens-and-supporting-parents-online?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e new safety features for teens, including a pop-up reminder to “take a break” from the app when they’ve been scrolling too long.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe announcement comes just one day ahead of when CEO Adam Mosseri will testify before Congress on the effects of Instagram on teens’ mental health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHere’s what else is new:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUsers will be restricted from tagging and mentioning teens who don’t follow them.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTeens will be “nudged” when they’ve spent too much time “dwelling” on one topic.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eParents and guardians will be able to view (and limit) how much time their teenage kids spend on Instagram.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome of these features are already rolling out, while others are set to hit the app in January.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Teens have ghosted Instagram from the get-go, and we mean that literally because their favorite social media platform is Snapchat, followed by TikTok, per a survey by Piper Sandler. That’s despite Instagram’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/16/technology/instagram-teens.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebest efforts\u003c/a\u003e to win them over: It copied Stories from Snapchat in 2016, and since 2018 it has reportedly spent nearly its entire marketing budget targeting teens, per the NYT.—\u003cem\u003eJW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable year you finally buy that Dyson vacuum cleaner, because companies plan to \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-plan-big-raises-for-workers-in-2022-11638889200?mod=hp_lead_pos10\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efatten up\u003c/a\u003e paychecks more than they have in over a decade, according to a Conference Board survey previewed by the WSJ yesterday. They’re setting aside an average of 3.9% of next year’s total payroll for wage increases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s a sign that salaries will continue to rise in 2022, like they have been doing all year:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePrivate-sector hourly pay rose 4.8% last month compared to Nov. 2020, the fifth straight month wages have risen more than 4%, the Labor Department reported Friday.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCompensation including wages and benefits rose faster in the third quarter of this year than at any other point on record.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy now? \u003c/strong\u003eDue to the ongoing labor shortage, employers are paying up to attract and retain the best and brightest. Plus, the cost of living is increasing: Almost four-in-ten of the companies surveyed said they factored inflation into their decisions to increase pay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut beware of the “\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/why-is-inflation-bad?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewage–price spiral\u003c/a\u003e.” When companies raise wages to combat inflation, they’re often forced to raise prices on consumers, which leads to even more inflation.—\u003cem\u003eJW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\"
